content: I think we need some sort of central bank but it should be under the control of congress, well regulated and transparent. The privately owned FED is the real culprit and has been since it's inception.

content: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: quote: ... but it should be under the control of congress, well regulated and transparent. You've GOT to be kidding ... name one thing under the control of Congress that is well-regulated and transparent. The Treasurey Department answers to Congress. Your issue is with the Constitution then. The Treasury should control the regulation of money not some private bank. Reagan removed the authority to investigate silver sales and bond regulation and reversed Kennedy's attempt to wrest control from the FED with EO 12608. The FED has a lot to do with where we are today.
quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: quote: ... but it should be under the control of congress, well regulated and transparent. You've GOT to be kidding ... name one thing under the control of Congress that is well-regulated and transparent.

You've GOT to be kidding ... name one thing under the control of Congress that is well-regulated and transparent. Andrew Jackson knew that too and busted up the National Bank of America. content: quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: Economics...not my strong suit so I have to ask, what is so bad about a National Bank especially if they were in competition with private banks? Just asking... Read the history, Jackson vs. Biddle. Jackson despised the idea, since unelected people gained undue power and control over the nation's economy. But leaving an economically powerful bank purely at the polytickle whim and fancy of an obviously irresponsible Congress, and you'll just get more and more of the nonsense the nation is now paying for from the likes of Frank, Dodd, and others. The wisdom and discipline of the Congress directly impacted what happened or not with the credit and mortgage crisis.
quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: Economics...not my strong suit so I have to ask, what is so bad about a National Bank especially if they were in competition with private banks? Just asking...
reply: Read the history, Jackson vs. Biddle. Jackson despised the idea, since unelected people gained undue power and control over the nation's economy. But leaving an economically powerful bank purely at the polytickle whim and fancy of an obviously irresponsible Congress, and you'll just get more and more of the nonsense the nation is now paying for from the likes of Frank, Dodd, and others. The wisdom and discipline of the Congress directly impacted what happened or not with the credit and mortgage crisis.
title: What is so bad about a National Bank?
